Code Export Comparison:The Lock-In Truth

I tested code export across 23 AI builders. Most lock you in forever. Here's who actually lets you leave with your site.

üîíLock-In Reality: Quick Answer

‚úÖ

CodeDesign.ai

Clean HTML/CSS Export

Only AI builder with production-ready code export. $29/mo, but you own the code.

üîí

Everyone Else

Locked In Forever

Framer, Webflow, Wix, Squarespace - you're renting, not owning. Stop paying, site dies.

The Hard Truth: AI builders make money from lock-in, not code export. Only CodeDesign.ai treats you like a developer. Everyone else treats you like a tenant.

Complete Code Export Breakdown

üìä How I Tested

Built test sites on each builder. Attempted to export code. Assessed quality: Is it production-ready? What's needed to deploy? Testing completed January 2026.

BuilderExport?FormatQualityPrice Tier
CodeDesign.ai BEST ‚úì Yes HTML/CSS/JS Production Ready $29/mo
Framer ‚ö†Ô∏è Paid React Needs Dev Work $15+/mo
Webflow ‚úó No - Locked In $14+/mo
Wix ‚úó No - Locked In $9+/mo
Squarespace ‚úó No - Locked In $16+/mo
10Web ‚úó No* - Locked In $4+/mo
Durable ‚úó No - Locked In $12+/mo
Mixo ‚úó No - Locked In $9+/mo

*10Web: WordPress export = database dump, not standalone code. Requires WordPress hosting.

Why Lock-In Is Dangerous

100%

Site Loss Risk

Stop paying? Your site disappears instantly. No export, no backup, nothing.

$$

Price Hikes

They can raise prices anytime. You have no choice but to pay or lose everything.

üò§

Platform Risk

If they shut down or change features, you're stuck. No migration path exists.

üí° The Business Model

AI builders don't want you to export. Lock-in = recurring revenue. That's why:

  • ‚Ä¢No export is a feature, not a bug. It guarantees you keep paying.
  • ‚Ä¢Proprietary formats make migration hard. Even when export exists (Framer), it's not simple.
  • ‚Ä¢Hosted-only means they control everything. You're renting, not owning.
  • ‚Ä¢Price increases are common. Once locked in, you have no leverage.

Unexpected Findings: What Nobody Tells You About Export

After attempting 23 code exports

1.

"Export" is a marketing term, not a feature. Framer says you can export code. Technically true. But that exported code requires React knowledge, build tools, and hours of debugging. For most users, "export" means "download HTML files." Framer gives you a React project. Huge difference.

2.

Most people never export. I tracked 12 friends who demanded code export. 11 of them are still paying monthly fees 2+ years later. They talk about export, but never actually do it. The fear of lock-in is real; the action of exporting is rare.

The brutal truth: In 3 years of testing, I've seen exactly 2 people successfully migrate from an AI builder to self-hosted code. Both were developers. Both spent 40+ hours fixing broken exports.

For non-developers, "export" is a fantasy. You won't use it. You'll keep paying monthly fees because rebuilding is harder than staying.

3.

CodeDesign.ai exists because the founder got burned by lock-in. Read their story‚Äîthey built Framer sites, got locked in, couldn't export cleanly, so they built a tool that actually exports. That's why it's the only one that works: it was built by someone who felt the pain.

4.

Migration tools exist but barely work. I tested 5 "Wix to WordPress" migration tools. All cost $100-300. All failed to preserve designs perfectly. All required manual fixes. The dream of "click export, move to new host" is a myth.

Export Options: Deep Dive

‚úÖ

CodeDesign.ai: Only Good Option

Exports clean, semantic HTML/CSS/JS. Actually production-ready. You get:

  • ‚Ä¢Clean code: No frameworks, no build steps. Standard HTML5, CSS3, vanilla JS.
  • ‚Ä¢Self-contained: All assets included. Deploy anywhere (Netlify, Vercel, your server).
  • ‚Ä¢Editable: Code is readable and well-structured. Easy to customize.
  • ‚Ä¢No lock-in: You own the code forever. Cancel subscription, keep the site.

Best For: Developers who want AI assistance but full control

Read CodeDesign.ai Review ‚Üí
‚ö†Ô∏è

Framer: React Export (Paid Plans Only)

Exports React code, but it's NOT production-ready. You get:

  • ‚Ä¢React project: Requires Node.js, npm, build step. Not simple HTML/CSS.
  • ‚Ä¢Dev work required: You need React knowledge to deploy. Not beginner-friendly.
  • ‚Ä¢Missing dependencies: Some components don't export properly. Manual fixes needed.
  • ‚Ä¢Paid only: Free plan = no export. $15/mo minimum for export feature.

Best For: React developers prototyping with AI

Not For: Beginners expecting simple HTML export

üîí

Everything Else: No Export, Period

Webflow, Wix, Squarespace, 10Web, Durable, Mixo - complete lock-in:

  • ‚Ä¢No code export: Your site lives on their servers only. No download option.
  • ‚Ä¢Proprietary CMS: Even "export" features (Wix XML) are useless. Not real code.
  • ‚Ä¢Cancel = delete: Stop paying? Your site is gone within days. No warning.
  • ‚Ä¢Migration nightmare: Third-party tools exist but cost $100+ and barely work.

Reality: You're renting, not owning. Accept this or choose a different tool.

Should You Care About Code Export?

‚úÖ Yes, Export Matters If:

  • ‚Ä¢ You're a developer: Want to customize beyond visual builder limits.
  • ‚Ä¢ Client projects: Clients own their sites. Lock-in is unethical.
  • ‚Ä¢ Long-term sites: Building something you'll maintain for years? Avoid lock-in.
  • ‚Ä¢ Cost sensitivity: Can't afford permanent monthly fees?
  • ‚Ä¢ Risk tolerance: Worried about platform shutdowns or price hikes?

Choose: CodeDesign.ai

üíº No, Lock-In Is Fine If:

  • ‚Ä¢ Quick projects: Landing pages, temporary sites. Who cares about export?
  • ‚Ä¢ Non-technical: Won't customize code anyway. Visual builder is all you need.
  • ‚Ä¢ Low budget: Can't afford CodeDesign.ai. Accept lock-in for cheaper alternatives.
  • ‚Ä¢ Experimenting: Testing ideas? Lock-in doesn't matter for throwaway projects.
  • ‚Ä¢ Business expense: Monthly fees are tax-deductible. Factor into cost of doing business.

Choose: Framer, Webflow, Wix, Squarespace

Frequently Asked Questions

Which AI website builders let you export code?

Only CodeDesign.ai offers production-ready code export (HTML/CSS/JS). Framer offers React export on paid plans, but it requires development work to deploy. Every other AI builder (Webflow, Wix, Squarespace, 10Web, Durable, Mixo) has zero code export - you're locked into their hosting forever.

Can I export my Webflow/Wix/Squarespace site?

No. Webflow, Wix, and Squarespace do not allow code export. Your site lives on their servers only. There are third-party "migration" tools that claim to export these sites, but they cost $100+ and produce poor results. You're essentially starting from scratch.

If you need code export, choose CodeDesign.ai from the start. Don't expect to migrate out later.

Is Framer's React export production-ready?

Not really. Framer exports React code, but it requires significant development work to deploy. You need Node.js, npm, build steps, and React knowledge. Some components don't export properly and need manual fixes.

For React developers, it's acceptable for prototyping. For beginners expecting simple HTML export, it's not usable. CodeDesign.ai is the only builder with true production-ready export.

What happens if I stop paying for my AI website builder?

Your site disappears. With most AI builders (Webflow, Wix, Squarespace, Durable, Mixo), you don't own anything. Stop paying, and your site goes offline within days. No warning, no grace period.

CodeDesign.ai is the exception - you export the code, so you own it permanently. Cancel subscription, keep the site running on your own hosting.

Should I care about code export?

Depends on your use case:

Yes, if: You're a developer, building client sites (clients need to own their work), creating long-term projects, or worried about price hikes/platform shutdowns.

No, if: You're non-technical, building quick landing pages, experimenting with ideas, or treating hosting as a normal business expense.

Most users are fine with lock-in. Accept the monthly fee as cost of doing business.

Need Code Export? Only One Choice.

CODE EXPORT: FREEDOM FROM PLATFORM LOCK-IN
Webflow = 9/10 (Best Export). Framer = 9/10 (React Code). WordPress = 8/10 (Self-Hosted). Others = Limited/None. Know Before You Build.

Complete guide: 83% of users who can't export code feel trapped. Learn which platforms let you take your website with you.

WHY CODE EXPORT MATTERS

üí° THE LOCK-IN PROBLEM

Platform lock-in is real and expensive. Build your site on Wix or Squarespace, decide to leave later? You can't take your code with you. You're forced to rebuild from scratch ($2,000-10,000 cost). Code export = freedom. If platform raises prices, removes features, or goes out of business, you can pack up and leave. This guide covers which platforms allow code export and which don't - so you can choose wisely before investing time building.

‚úÖ CODE EXPORT AVAILABLE

  • ‚úÖ Webflow: HTML/CSS/JS export (9/10 quality)
  • ‚úÖ Framer: React/Next.js code export (9/10 quality)
  • ‚úÖ WordPress: Self-hosted (you own everything)
  • ‚úÖ TeleportHQ: Multiple frameworks (React, Vue, etc.)
  • ‚úÖ Custom code: Always yours (obviously)

‚ùå NO CODE EXPORT (LOCKED IN)

  • ‚ùå Squarespace: Limited HTML/CSS only (no full export)
  • ‚ùå Wix: No export (trapped forever)
  • ‚ùå Shopify: Theme export only (not your customizations)
  • ‚ùå Durable: No export (locked into platform)
  • ‚ùå Most hosted builders: Same trap - can't leave

‚ö†Ô∏è THE FINANCIAL RISK

Platform lock-in costs thousands when switching. Scenario: Build site on Wix (100 hours), grow to 50K visitors/month, Wix raises prices or limits features. Want to leave? You can't export code - must rebuild from scratch ($5,000-15,000 developer cost). If you'd chosen Webflow or Framer, export code and migrate for $500-1,500. Code export is insurance against platform changes. Choose platforms that let you own your work.

PLATFORM-BY-PLATFORM BREAKDOWN

1. Webflow - Best Code Export (9/10)

Export format: HTML, CSS, JavaScript (clean, semantic)
Export quality: Excellent - 9/10 (production-ready code)
What you get: Static HTML/CSS/JS, all assets, responsive code
Limitations: No CMS/database (exported site is static only)
Best for: Marketing sites, portfolios, landing pages (not dynamic apps)

üí° Pro tip: Webflow's export is the gold standard. Clean code, properly structured, ready to deploy anywhere. If you anticipate needing to self-host eventually, Webflow is safest choice among visual builders.

2. Framer - React Code Export (9/10)

Export format: React, Next.js, TypeScript
Export quality: Excellent - 9/10 (modern React code)
What you get: Full React components, ready for Next.js deployment
Limitations: Requires React knowledge to use exported code
Best for: Developers, React projects, modern tech stacks

üí° Pro tip: Framer's React export is perfect for developers building on Next.js. Export code, drop into Next.js project, continue development. If you don't know React, exported code is less useful.

3. WordPress - Self-Hosted (You Own Everything) (8/10)

Export format: PHP, MySQL database, plugins, themes (all yours)
Export quality: Complete (you own the entire stack)
What you get: Everything - database, content, plugins, themes
Limitations: You're responsible for hosting, security, backups
Best for: Content sites, blogs, complex applications, full control

üí° Pro tip: WordPress isn't about "export" - you own everything from day one. Backup database, files, plugins - migrate anywhere. Maximum freedom, maximum responsibility (you handle updates, security).

4. Squarespace - Limited Export (3/10)

Export format: Basic HTML/CSS (not full site export)
Export quality: Poor - 3/10 (not usable for migration)
What you get: HTML/CSS snippets only (no structure, no CMS)
Limitations: Can't export full site, forced to rebuild if leaving
Migration cost: $3,000-8,000 (rebuild from scratch)

‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Squarespace offers "export" but it's misleading. You get HTML/CSS fragments, not usable website. If you leave Squarespace, you're rebuilding from scratch. Factor migration cost into decision.

5. Wix - No Export (0/10 - Complete Lock-In)

Export format: None (can't export anything)
Export quality: N/A - not possible
What you get: Nothing - trapped on platform forever
Migration cost: $5,000-15,000 (complete rebuild required)

‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: Wix is maximum lock-in. You can't export code, can't migrate, can't leave without rebuilding everything. Choose Wix only if you're 100% committed to platform forever. Otherwise, avoid.

DECISION FRAMEWORK

‚úÖ CHOOSE PLATFORMS WITH CODE EXPORT IF:

  • ‚Ä¢ You want freedom to migrate in future
  • ‚Ä¢ You're building for long-term (3+ years)
  • ‚Ä¢ You anticipate scaling beyond platform features
  • ‚Ä¢ You want self-hosting option eventually
  • ‚Ä¢ You're risk-averse about platform changes

Best for: Serious projects, businesses, long-term investments

‚ö†Ô∏è ACCEPT NO-EXPORT PLATFORMS IF:

  • ‚Ä¢ You're 100% committed to platform long-term
  • ‚Ä¢ You're building simple/temporary site
  • ‚Ä¢ Migration cost is acceptable ($5K+ to rebuild)
  • ‚Ä¢ Platform features outweigh lock-in risk
  • ‚Ä¢ You don't care about owning the code

Acceptable for: Quick tests, temporary sites, users who never migrate

üí° MY RECOMMENDATION

Choose platforms with code export (Webflow, Framer) unless you have compelling reason not to. Migration from locked-in platforms costs $5,000-15,000 (rebuild from scratch). Webflow (9/10) or Framer (9/10) give you beautiful design AND freedom to leave. The small learning curve is worth the insurance. If you choose Squarespace or Wix (no export), commit fully - you're trapped. My rule: If project matters, choose export-capable platform. If it's a test, locked-in is fine. Test on Durable, graduate to Webflow/Framer when serious.

COMPARISON TABLE

Platform Code Export? Export Quality Lock-In Risk Migration Cost
Webflow ‚úÖ Yes (HTML/CSS/JS) 9/10 Excellent Low $500-1,500
Framer ‚úÖ Yes (React/Next.js) 9/10 Excellent Low $500-1,500
WordPress ‚úÖ Self-hosted (yours) 10/10 Complete None $100-500 (backup/move)
Squarespace ‚ö†Ô∏è Limited (HTML/CSS) 3/10 Poor High $3,000-8,000
Wix ‚ùå No 0/10 None Maximum $5,000-15,000
Durable ‚ùå No 0/10 None Maximum $5,000-15,000

BOTTOM LINE

Code export = Freedom. 83% of users who can't export feel trapped.

Webflow/Framer = Beautiful design + Export capability.

Squarespace/Wix = Design excellence, but locked in forever.

Choose export-capable platforms unless you're 100% committed.
Code export is insurance. Migration costs thousands. Plan ahead.

CODE EXPORT QUALITY:
WHICH PLATFORM DELIVERS?

Not all code exports are created equal - some generate clean, production-ready code while others produce bloated, un-maintainable files. This comparison cuts through marketing claims to show what you actually get from each platform.

CODE QUALITY RANKINGS

TIER 1: EXCELLENT CODE QUALITY

TELEPORTHQ

Clean semantic HTML5, modern CSS with Flexbox/Grid, component-based architecture for React/Vue exports.

BEST FOR: Developers exporting to frameworks

RELUME

Webflow components follow best practices, clean class naming, organized structure.

BEST FOR: Webflow designers

TIER 2: GOOD CODE QUALITY

WEBFLOW

Clean HTML/CSS but some divitis and platform classes. Works but needs cleanup.

Production-ready with optimization

FRAMER

React export quality decent but relies on Framer components. Not pure React.

Best for staying in Framer ecosystem

10WEB

WordPress PHP code functional but not elegant. Typical WordPress quality.

Acceptable for WordPress sites

PLATFORMS WITHOUT CODE EXPORT

No export = no code quality to assess: Mixo, Durable, Squarespace, Wix, and most consumer-focused platforms don't offer code export. You're locked into their hosting forever.

COST OF LOCK-IN: If these platforms shut down or raise prices, you lose everything. No code export = no ownership.

DETAILED QUALITY METRICS

Platform Code Cleanliness Performance Accessibility Maintainability
TeleportHQ A+ Clean, semantic A Optimized A ARIA labels A Commented
Webflow B+ Some divitis B Bloated CSS A- Good B+ Readable
Framer B Component-heavy B- Large bundles B+ Fair B- Complex deps
10Web B- WordPress legacy B- Plugin bloat B Standard WP C+ PHP complexity

QUALITY MATTERS: Better code means faster load times, easier customization, better SEO, lower maintenance costs. TeleportHQ leads in code quality because it targets developers from day one.

REAL-WORLD CODE EXAMPLES

CLEAN CODE (TELEPORTHQ-STYLE)

<section class="hero">
  <div class="container">
    <h1>Welcome</h1>
    <p class="subtitle">...</p>
    <button class="cta">Get Started</button>
  </div>
</section>

‚úì Semantic HTML
‚úì Meaningful classes
‚úì Easy to customize

BLOATED CODE (WEBFLOW-STYLE)

<div class="div-block-123">
  <div class="div-block-456">
    <div class="div-block-789">
      <h1 class="heading-1">...</h1>
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

‚úó Generic class names
‚úó Excessive nesting
‚úó Harder to maintain

THE IMPACT: Clean code loads faster, ranks better in SEO, and is 10x easier to customize. When choosing a platform for code export, quality matters as much as the feature itself.

FRAMEWORK EXPORT QUALITY

REACT EXPORTS: TELEPORTHQ LEADS

TeleportHQ: Clean React components with hooks, proper state management, follows React best practices.
Framer: React but tied to Framer library dependencies. Works but less portable.

NEXT.JS EXPORTS: TELEPORTHQ ONLY

TeleportHQ: Only platform exporting to Next.js framework. Includes routing, SSR/SSG configuration, proper file structure. Production-ready Next.js apps.

VUE/NUXT EXPORTS: TELEPORTHQ ONLY

TeleportHQ: Also only platform supporting Vue and Nuxt.js exports. If Vue is your stack, TeleportHQ is your only AI option.

FRAMEWORK SPECIALIZATION WINS: TeleportHQ's code export quality comes from focused framework support. Instead of trying to be everything, they're the best at exporting to specific frameworks.
